title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Third and Six
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(cfbfastR)
library(scales)



load the play-by-play data


Code
plays <- load_cfb_pbp(seasons = c(2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023))




Code
third_and_six <- plays |> filter(down == 3, distance == 6)




Code
third_and_six_grouped <- third_and_six |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))

third_and_six_grouped


# A tibble: 19 × 2
   play_type                            count
   <chr>                                <int>
 1 Pass Reception                        3596
 2 Pass Incompletion                     2956
 3 Rush                                  2420
 4 Penalty                                828
 5 Timeout                                694
 6 Sack                                   631
 7 Passing Touchdown                      392
 8 Interception Return                    188
 9 Rushing Touchdown                      102
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)              85
11 Fumble Recovery (Own)                   56
12 Interception Return Touchdown           26
13 Field Goal Good                         13
14 Field Goal Missed                        4
15 Fumble Return Touchdown                  3
16 Punt                                     3
17 Safety                                   2
18 Blocked Field Goal                       1
19 Fumble Recovery (Opponent) Touchdown     1


The most frequent play type is a Pass Reception, with over 3,400 occurrences from 2019 to 2023.


Code
third_and_six_grouped |>
  mutate(pct = (count/11655)*100)


# A tibble: 19 × 3
   play_type                            count      pct
   <chr>                                <int>    <dbl>
 1 Pass Reception                        3596 30.9    
 2 Pass Incompletion                     2956 25.4    
 3 Rush                                  2420 20.8    
 4 Penalty                                828  7.10   
 5 Timeout                                694  5.95   
 6 Sack                                   631  5.41   
 7 Passing Touchdown                      392  3.36   
 8 Interception Return                    188  1.61   
 9 Rushing Touchdown                      102  0.875  
10 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)              85  0.729  
11 Fumble Recovery (Own)                   56  0.480  
12 Interception Return Touchdown           26  0.223  
13 Field Goal Good                         13  0.112  
14 Field Goal Missed                        4  0.0343 
15 Fumble Return Touchdown                  3  0.0257 
16 Punt                                     3  0.0257 
17 Safety                                   2  0.0172 
18 Blocked Field Goal                       1  0.00858
19 Fumble Recovery (Opponent) Touchdown     1  0.00858


When I added all occurrences for each type of play, I got 11,655. There were 2,359 rush/run plays from 2019 to 2023, and they accounted for about 20.24% of all types of plays during that same period.


Code
third_and_six_yards_gained <- third_and_six |>
  select(play_type, yards_gained) |>
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarize(yards_gained = sum(yards_gained))

third_and_six_yards_gained


# A tibble: 19 × 2
   play_type                            yards_gained
   <chr>                                       <dbl>
 1 Blocked Field Goal                             48
 2 Field Goal Good                               436
 3 Field Goal Missed                             202
 4 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)                    307
 5 Fumble Recovery (Opponent) Touchdown            0
 6 Fumble Recovery (Own)                          70
 7 Fumble Return Touchdown                       141
 8 Interception Return                           188
 9 Interception Return Touchdown                 403
10 Pass Incompletion                             240
11 Pass Reception                              40481
12 Passing Touchdown                            8101
13 Penalty                                       146
14 Punt                                            0
15 Rush                                        13713
16 Rushing Touchdown                            1700
17 Sack                                        -3965
18 Safety                                         -5
19 Timeout                                         0


The total yards gained for rush/run plays from 2019 to 2023 is 13,286 yards, and since there were 2,359 rush/run plays, we get an average of about 5.632 yards gained per play.


Code
third_and_six_teams_2019 <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush", year == 2019) |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_2019


# A tibble: 125 × 2
   home             rush_play_count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Navy                          13
 2 Georgia Southern              11
 3 Notre Dame                    10
 4 Oklahoma State                 8
 5 Old Dominion                   8
 6 Pittsburgh                     8
 7 Florida State                  7
 8 Nebraska                       7
 9 Oregon                         7
10 Toledo                         7
# ℹ 115 more rows




Code
third_and_six_teams_2020 <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush", year == 2020) |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_2020


# A tibble: 103 × 2
   home             rush_play_count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 NC State                       8
 2 Navy                           8
 3 North Texas                    8
 4 Army                           7
 5 Tulane                         7
 6 Air Force                      5
 7 Auburn                         5
 8 Georgia Southern               5
 9 Kansas State                   5
10 Pittsburgh                     5
# ℹ 93 more rows




Code
third_and_six_teams_2021 <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush", year == 2021) |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_2021


# A tibble: 124 × 2
   home              rush_play_count
   <chr>                       <int>
 1 Arkansas                       13
 2 Air Force                      11
 3 Army                            9
 4 Baylor                          9
 5 Ole Miss                        9
 6 Wyoming                         9
 7 Navy                            8
 8 Northern Illinois               8
 9 Tulane                          8
10 Coastal Carolina                7
# ℹ 114 more rows




Code
third_and_six_teams_2022 <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush", year == 2022) |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_2022


# A tibble: 232 × 2
   home               rush_play_count
   <chr>                        <int>
 1 Florida                          8
 2 Georgia                          8
 3 Mercer                           8
 4 South Dakota State               8
 5 Alabama State                    7
 6 Duke                             7
 7 Navy                             7
 8 North Carolina                   7
 9 Towson                           7
10 Air Force                        6
# ℹ 222 more rows




Code
third_and_six_teams_2023 <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush", year == 2023) |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_2023


# A tibble: 190 × 2
   home             rush_play_count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Army                           6
 2 Louisiana                      6
 3 Arkansas State                 5
 4 Connecticut                    5
 5 Georgia State                  5
 6 Mercer                         5
 7 Prairie View                   5
 8 Tennessee Tech                 5
 9 Virginia Tech                  5
10 Western Michigan               5
# ℹ 180 more rows




Code
third_and_six_teams_total <- third_and_six |>
  filter(play_type == "Rush") |> 
  group_by(home) |>
  summarize(rush_play_count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(rush_play_count))

third_and_six_teams_total


# A tibble: 252 × 2
   home             rush_play_count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Navy                          40
 2 Army                          30
 3 Tulane                        29
 4 Air Force                     28
 5 Baylor                        25
 6 Georgia Southern              23
 7 Michigan                      23
 8 Ole Miss                      23
 9 Bowling Green                 22
10 Pittsburgh                    22
# ℹ 242 more rows


The Navy had the most rush/run plays in 2019. There was a three-way tie in 2020 for NC State, the Navy and North Texas. Arkansas had the most rush/run plays in 2021. There was a four-way tie in 2022 for Florida, Georgia, Mercer, and South Dakota State. The Army had the most rush/run plays in 2023. From 2019 to 2023, the Navy had the most rush/run plays out of every team.


Maryland


Code
third_and_six_md_grouped <- third_and_six |>
  filter(home == "Maryland") |> 
  group_by(play_type) |>
  summarize(count = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(count))

third_and_six_md_grouped


# A tibble: 10 × 2
   play_type                  count
   <chr>                      <int>
 1 Pass Reception                25
 2 Rush                          16
 3 Pass Incompletion             14
 4 Penalty                        6
 5 Sack                           4
 6 Timeout                        3
 7 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)     1
 8 Interception Return            1
 9 Passing Touchdown              1
10 Rushing Touchdown              1




Code
third_and_six_md_grouped |>
  mutate(pct = (count/72)*100)


# A tibble: 10 × 3
   play_type                  count   pct
   <chr>                      <int> <dbl>
 1 Pass Reception                25 34.7 
 2 Rush                          16 22.2 
 3 Pass Incompletion             14 19.4 
 4 Penalty                        6  8.33
 5 Sack                           4  5.56
 6 Timeout                        3  4.17
 7 Fumble Recovery (Opponent)     1  1.39
 8 Interception Return            1  1.39
 9 Passing Touchdown              1  1.39
10 Rushing Touchdown              1  1.39


Maryland had ten types of plays from 2019 to 2023, with the most frequent of them being Pass Receptions, accounting for about 34.722% of all plays. This was surprising to me, as this is one of three play types that Maryland seems to be focusing on during football, whereas the other seven listed have less than 10 occurrences from 2019 to 2023. This makes me think that because Maryland focuses on the pass receptions, rushes/runs and pass incompletions, they would often do well in games, but because they aren’t focusing on anything else, they would come up less than stellar in games. So it’s honestly a bit of a mixed bag here.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=third_and_six_md_grouped, 
    aes(x=reorder(play_type, count),
        weight=count)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="Maryland's dominant play from 2019 to 2023 is pass receptions", 
    x="Type of play", 
    y="Count (from 2019 to 2023") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()

title: Reverse Engineering the 538 Article
Maryland’s Big Ten performance growing lackluster since 2021
text:
Here I am loading the necessary functions.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
library(ggrepel)


Here I am loading the football logs.


Code
logs <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs1123.csv")


Rows: 19934 Columns: 55
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (46): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Here I am counting the total number of wins per team.


Code
winlosslogs <- logs |> 
  mutate(
    wins = case_when(
      grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1, 
      grepl("L", Outcome) ~ 0)
)


Here I am calculating the Total Offensive and Defensive Plays, Total Offensive and Defensive Yards, Total Wins, and Offensive and Defensive Yards Per Play.


Code
winlosslogs |> 
  group_by(Team, Season) |> 
  summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays), 
    TotalYards = sum(OffensiveYards), 
    DefensivePlays = sum(DefPlays), 
    DefensiveYards = sum(DefYards), 
    TotalWins = sum(wins)) |> 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards/TotalPlays, 
    DefensiveYPP = DefensiveYards/DefensivePlays) -> ypp


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Team'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Here I am plotting the points showing Offensive and Defensive Yards Per Play for each team between the 2011 and 2023 seasons.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP)
    )





Here I am making the size of the points based on Total Wins.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins)
    )





Here I am making the points more transluscent and adding a scale showing the number of wins.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins),
    alpha = .3) + 
  scale_size(range = c(3, 8), name="Wins")





Here I am filtering for the team of Maryland and highlighting their points in red.


Code
maryland <- ypp |> filter(Team == "Maryland")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red")





Here I am calculating the X and Y intercepts of the graph.


Code
ypp |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  summarise(
    offense = mean(OffensiveYPP), 
    defense = mean(DefensiveYPP)
    )


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  offense defense
    <dbl>   <dbl>
1    5.73    5.61


Here I am putting lines on the graph with the X and Y-intercept information.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.734061) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.608837)





Here I am adding labels for points representing the team of Maryland for each season.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.734061) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.608837) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, label=Season)
  )





Here I am adding a lede title and description to the graph.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) + 
  geom_point(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.734061) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.608837) + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data=maryland, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, label=Season)
  ) +
  labs(title="Maryland's Big Ten performance growing lackluster since 2021", subtitle="The Terps offense and defense for the past few years are considerably lower, especially when ranked with \nother teams from 2011 to 2023.", caption="Source: NCAA | By Mitchell Hang")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )





I think this is an interesting depiction on how Maryland’s Big Ten performance has changed over the years, because I was initially expecting some increase, but in actuality it’s often gone below the X-axis in recent years (i.e., after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic). It can be considered that 2021 was their best year since their Defensive and Offensive Yards per Play were above and to the right of their respective axes – they are in the so-called positive-positive quadrant (I) – whereas 2022 appears to be the worst in recent years as they are in the negative-negative quadrant (III). I don’t think there’s an easy way to signify that the 2023 data is incomplete, as we already have tons of data from other teams that have already blended in with one another, but maybe making the point for 2023 a darker color could be a potential solution.

title: Purdue dethroned in average offensive plays for 2023 NCAA football season
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(scales)


Here I am loading the library items that will help me construct my code for this exercise.


Code
logs_22 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs22.csv")

logs_23 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")


Here I am loading the two online datasets for 2022 and 2023 separately into RStudio.


Code
big10 <- c("Nebraska Cornhuskers", "Iowa Hawkeyes", "Minnesota Golden Gophers", "Illinois Fighting Illini", "Northwestern Wildcats", "Wisconsin Badgers", "Indiana Hoosiers", "Purdue Boilermakers", "Ohio State Buckeyes", "Michigan Wolverines", "Michigan State Spartans", "Penn State Nittany Lions", "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", "Maryland Terrapins")


This code block constructs a filter category of all the Big Ten colleges to be used in the 2022 and 2023 datasets. Alternatively, one could filter the datasets directly by conference.


Code
logs_22_filtered <- logs_22 |> 
  filter(TeamFull %in% big10) |>
  select(TeamFull, OffensivePlays) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    TotalOffensivePlays = sum(OffensivePlays),
    GamesPlayed = n(),
    AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame = (TotalOffensivePlays/GamesPlayed)) |>
  arrange(desc(AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame))

show(logs_22_filtered)


# A tibble: 14 × 4
   TeamFull               TotalOffensivePlays GamesPlayed AvgOffensivePlaysPer…¹
   <chr>                                <dbl>       <int>                  <dbl>
 1 Purdue Boilermakers                   1049          14                   74.9
 2 Northwestern Wildcats                  886          12                   73.8
 3 Indiana Hoosiers                       879          12                   73.2
 4 Illinois Fighting Ill…                 938          13                   72.2
 5 Maryland Terrapins                     915          13                   70.4
 6 Penn State Nittany Li…                 911          13                   70.1
 7 Michigan Wolverines                    970          14                   69.3
 8 Ohio State Buckeyes                    876          13                   67.4
 9 Minnesota Golden Goph…                 862          13                   66.3
10 Michigan State Sparta…                 773          12                   64.4
11 Wisconsin Badgers                      827          13                   63.6
12 Rutgers Scarlet Knigh…                 762          12                   63.5
13 Nebraska Cornhuskers                   761          12                   63.4
14 Iowa Hawkeyes                          772          13                   59.4
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame


Here, I am mutating the 2022 dataset to show the results I would like. I begin by implementing the Big Ten filter category, selecting only the columns showing the full team name and the number of offensive plays for each game, and grouping by the full team name. Then, I use the summarise/ze function to create new columns showing the total number of offensive plays for each team, the number of games each team played during the season, and the calculated average number of offensive plays per game for each team. I then arranged the teams in descending order by the latter column, and we can see that the Purdue Boilermakers have a wide lead for their total offensive plays, thereby resulting them having the highest average offensive plays per game during the 2022 season, as there is about one play separating the Boilermakers and the Northwestern Wildcats and half a play separating the Wildcats and the Indiana Hoosiers. I would say that these team results are relatively close to one another.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=logs_22_filtered, 
    aes(x=reorder(TeamFull, AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame),
        weight=AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="Purdue out on top in average offensive plays for 2022", 
    x="Team", 
    y="Average # of offensive plays per game") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()





Here, I am constructing a stacked bar graph that shows the average number of offensive plays for each team in the Big Ten Conference for the 2022 college football season. I decided to go with a stacked bar graph because the names of the teams are quite long and they would cross into one another otherwise, and also because it will be easier to see any differences from one team to another rather than a regular (i.e., vertical) bar graph.
This graph, we can see that Purdue has the highest average number of offensive plays for all Big Ten colleges during the 2022 college football season. There are relatively small margins from one team to another on this graph, with the largest separation being between the Nebraska Cornhuskers and the Iowa Hawkeyes. Some teams have played for fewer games compared to Purdue (they have played the most, at 14 games) during the 2022 season, and it’s possible that the ranking would’ve changed had they played more games.


Code
logs_23_filtered <- logs_23 |> 
  filter(TeamFull %in% big10) |>
  select(TeamFull, OffensivePlays) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    TotalOffensivePlays = sum(OffensivePlays),
    GamesPlayed = n(),
    AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame = (TotalOffensivePlays/GamesPlayed)) |>
  arrange(desc(AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame))

show(logs_23_filtered)


# A tibble: 14 × 4
   TeamFull               TotalOffensivePlays GamesPlayed AvgOffensivePlaysPer…¹
   <chr>                                <dbl>       <int>                  <dbl>
 1 Penn State Nittany Li…                 403           5                   80.6
 2 Purdue Boilermakers                    438           6                   73  
 3 Wisconsin Badgers                      357           5                   71.4
 4 Maryland Terrapins                     410           6                   68.3
 5 Michigan State Sparta…                 338           5                   67.6
 6 Illinois Fighting Ill…                 400           6                   66.7
 7 Northwestern Wildcats                  399           6                   66.5
 8 Indiana Hoosiers                       332           5                   66.4
 9 Minnesota Golden Goph…                 382           6                   63.7
10 Ohio State Buckeyes                    314           5                   62.8
11 Rutgers Scarlet Knigh…                 373           6                   62.2
12 Nebraska Cornhuskers                   372           6                   62  
13 Michigan Wolverines                    358           6                   59.7
14 Iowa Hawkeyes                          333           6                   55.5
# ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame


Here, I am doing the exact same steps I used to mutate the 2022 dataset for the current 2023 dataset. Here, we can see that the Penn State Nittany Lions have overtaken the Purdue Boilermakers in average offensive plays per game in the 2023 season by about six plays. The Wisconsin Badgers have moved up considerably from last year’s ranking, as they are currently now behind Purdue by no more than two plays.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=logs_23_filtered, 
    aes(x=reorder(TeamFull, AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame),
        weight=AvgOffensivePlaysPerGame)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="Penn State overtakes Purdue in average offensive plays for 2023", 
    x="Team", 
    y="Average # of offensive plays per game") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()





Here, we see that the Penn Stake Nittany Lions have currently dethroned the Purdue Boilermakers for having the highest average offensive plays for all Big Ten colleges in the 2023 college football season, and it’s evident from the graph that there’s a much wider margin between the top two teams compared to the top 2 and top 3 teams, top 3 and top 4 teams, etc. It can be assumed that Penn State was pushing more offensive plays in their games since being ranked sixth in average offensive plays from last year. Interestingly, if we go back to the tibble from earlier, Penn State has played five games whereas Purdue has played six, and Purdue has a few dozen more offensive plays than Penn State. It’s possible that the separation between the current top two teams in average offensive plays wil grow larger once Penn State completes their sixth game.
In conclusion, I thought this was an interesting exercise in creating bar graphs to tell a story about a certain college’s rise or fall in the sports world. I was honestly surprised to see Purdue lose their lead in average offensive plays for another team, considering how dominant they were in having the highest offensive plays during the 2022 college football season. Considering that the 2023 college football season is still in progress, it’s unknown if the ranking will remain as is or if Purdue (or another team) takes back their lead, and maybe another team will make a surprising move up or down from last year’s ranking.

title: Hello World!
text:
This is a blog. The word “blog” rhymes with “dog.”
Welcome to my blog, dog.

title: Post With Code
text:
This is a post with executable code.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Running On Empty
text:
This week, I am attempting to reverse-engineer the FiveThirtyEight article, “The Best Red Zone Teams Are The Ones That Get There,” published on September 29, 2022: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-best-red-zone-teams-are-the-ones-that-get-there/
Here I am loading the necessary packages.


Code
library(tidyverse)


Here I am loading the football logs for 2023.


Code
logs <- read_csv("https://www.thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")


Rows: 1205 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Here I am filtering the original dataframe by teams currently in the Big Ten Conference.


Code
logs_big10 <- logs |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")


Here I am creating a line chart based on the Date and RushingAvg for each team in the Big Ten Conference.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=logs_big10, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-5, 10))





Here I am separating all of the lines for each team into separate graphs with a facet wrap.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=logs_big10, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-5, 10)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team)





Here I am calculating the mean and treating it as a baseline for each team’s graph.


Code
logs_big10 |> summarise(mean(RushingAvg))


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  `mean(RushingAvg)`
               <dbl>
1               3.82




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept=3.816667, color="blue") + 
  geom_line(data=logs_big10, aes(x=Date, y=RushingAvg, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-5, 10)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team)





If we take a look at Maryland, we can see that for the first five games of the 2023 season (September 2nd to September 30th) that Maryland’s has an above average rushing performance compared to a baseline of 3.816667 yards per carry. Starting from Game 6 (October 7th), we start to see a slight decline in rushing performance before returning to some level slightly above the baseline. However, the most recent game on November 4th reveals Maryland’s worst rushing performance thus far in the season, as it is way below the baseline (less than -3 yards per carry). Interestingly enough, the first five games with the above average rushing performances were those in which Maryland won, whereas they lost in the following four games.
When we compare Maryland’s rushing performance to other Big Ten teams during the same period, we can see that many of the other teams have different fluctuating (i.e., change from high to low) rushing performances in regards to the baseline, but Michigan seems to be the most consistent, as there is relatively little fluctuation and their first few games are rated above the baseline. The one graph that looks most similar to Maryland’s is Nebraska’s, as they both have above average rushing performances for games up to October 1st, followed by a slight decline before returning above the baseline, followed by another decline in rushing performance. It’s worth noting that Nebraska’s most recent rushing performance isn’t as bad as Maryland’s around the same time. However, the fact that Maryland’s most recent rushing performance falls far below not just the baseline but other teams in their recent games draws immediate concern, as it makes people wonder how they are doing so poorly in rushing, especially compared to their past performances in prior seasons.
If we analyze Maryland’s performance in the most recent game against Penn State alone, we can see that not only was their rushing performance below average, but also they had the fewest rushing attempts out of all games they played thus far (16). From this, it’s also worth noting that Maryland and Penn State games are often some of the most hyped within the universities, as the two have a growing football rivalry (largely helped by them currently being part of the same conference) going as far back as at least 1943, where both teams face up once a year in the fall, and Penn State wins most often. In fact, Penn State’s own sports website even chronicles many of their matches with Maryland in detail, mentioning that their longest winning streak lasted 24 games from 1962 to 1988, with the only times Maryland has won being in 1961, 2014 and 2020 (plus a tie in 1988). So it seems that Maryland losing to Penn State almost every year is perhaps a constant in life (something that might be presumed as inevitable despite the increased training), but once in a while, a miracle does happen and Maryland is able to pull out a victory (or at least tie).
https://gopsusports.com/sports/football/opponent-history/university-of-maryland/44

title: Volleyball
text:
Here I am loading the necessary functions.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
set.seed(1234)


Here I am loading the football logs.


Code
players <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensVolleyballData/main/data/ncaa_womens_volleyball_playerstats_2023.csv")


Rows: 5133 Columns: 33
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (7): team, full_name, roster_name, last_name, first_name, yr, pos
dbl (24): season, jersey, feet, inches, gp, gs, mp, s, kills, errors, total_...
lgl  (2): ms, total_blocks

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
activeplayers <- players |> 
  filter(mp>=20) |>
  filter(!is.na(aces), !is.na(pos))

activeplayers <- activeplayers |> mutate(acespermatch=(aces/mp))




Code
summary(activeplayers$acespermatch)


   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
 0.0000  0.1818  0.6000  0.6143  0.9500  2.4000 




Code
aceplayers <- activeplayers |> filter(acespermatch >= 0.9500)

ggplot() + geom_beeswarm(data=aceplayers, aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="grey")







Code
umd <- activeplayers |> 
  filter(team == "Maryland Terrapins, Terps") |> 
  filter(acespermatch >= 0.9500) |> 
  arrange(desc(acespermatch))

ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=aceplayers, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=umd, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="red")


Warning: The `groupOnX` argument of `geom_beeswarm()` is deprecated as of ggbeeswarm
0.7.1.
ℹ ggplot2 now handles this case automatically.







Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=aceplayers, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=umd, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="red") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=umd, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch, label=full_name)) +
  labs(title="Three UMD players have the highest aces per match", subtitle="The Terps' women's volleyball team currently has three players that have a calculated average of 0.95 or more \naces for every match they played, as they are ranked alongside many other players in other teams serving \ndifferent positions.", caption="Source: NCAA | By Mitchell Hang")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )





Lilly Gunter, a defensive specialist, has recently racked up 26 digs, a season-high, against Illinois (10/20). Sam Csire, an outside hitter, secured double-double with 12 kills and career-high 17 digs against Illinois (10/20) and was honored at the beginning of the semester as a member of the Maryland 1,000-Kill Club. Erin Engel, a setter, recently produced a pair of service aces in win over Iowa (10/21).
